official-title.#text:
To direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to
		  develop a national strategic action plan to assist health professionals in
		  preparing for and responding to the public health effects of climate change,
		  and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the
			 following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Climate Change Health Protection and
			 Promotion Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
that the
			 Federal Government, in cooperation with international, State, tribal, and local
			 governments, concerned public and private organizations, and citizens, should
			 use all practicable means and measures—

text.#text: It is the sense of the

header.#text:
Sense of Congress
			 on public health and climate change

text.#text:
to assist the
			 efforts of public health and health care professionals, first responders,
			 States, tribes, municipalities, and local communities to incorporate measures
			 to prepare health systems to respond to the impacts of climate change;
to ensure—

the utility and
			 value of scientific research in advancing understanding of—

the
			 health impacts of climate change; and

strategies to prepare for and respond to
			 the health impacts of climate change;

the identification
			 of communities vulnerable to the health effects of climate change and the
			 development of strategic response plans to be carried out by health
			 professionals for those communities;

the improvement of
			 health status and health equity through efforts to prepare for and respond to
			 climate change; and

the inclusion of
			 health policy in the development of climate change responses;

to encourage
			 further research, interdisciplinary partnership, and collaboration among
			 stakeholders in order to—

understand and
			 monitor the health impacts of climate change; and

improve public
			 health knowledge and response strategies to climate change;

to assist the
			 efforts of developing nations to incorporate measures to prepare health systems
			 to respond to the impacts of climate change.

Nothing in this Act
			 in any manner limits the authority provided to or responsibility conferred on
			 any Federal department or agency by any provision of any law (including
			 regulations) or authorizes any violation of any provision of any law (including
			 regulations), including any health, energy, environmental, transportation, or
			 any other law or regulation.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, within 2 years after the date of the enactment of
			 this Act, on the basis of the best available science, and in consultation
			 pursuant to
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Secretary of
			 Health and Human Services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall publish a strategic action plan to assist
			 health professionals in preparing for and responding to the impacts of climate
			 change on public health in the United States and other nations, particularly
			 developing nations.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Climate Change Health Protection and Promotion Act/s:4/ss:a/p:2

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall—

text.#text:
In
			 developing or making any revision to the national strategic action plan, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Director of the Centers
			 for Disease Control and Prevention

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Administrator of the Environmental
			 Protection Agency

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the National Institutes of Health

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, other appropriate Federal agencies, Indian tribes, State
			 and local governments, public health organizations, scientists, and other
			 interested stakeholders; and

text.#text: consult with the

provide
			 opportunity for public input.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , acting through the

, shall assist health professionals in
			 preparing for and responding effectively and efficiently to the health effects
			 of climate change through measures including—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Director of the Centers
			 for Disease Control and Prevention

text.#text: The

developing,
			 improving, integrating, and maintaining domestic and international disease
			 surveillance systems and monitoring capacity to respond to health-related
			 effects of climate change, including on topics addressing—

water, food, and
			 vector borne infectious diseases and climate change;

pulmonary
			 effects, including responses to aeroallergens;

cardiovascular
			 effects, including impacts of temperature extremes;

air pollution health effects, including
			 heightened sensitivity to air pollution;

hazardous algal
			 blooms;

mental and
			 behavioral health impacts of climate change;

the health of
			 refugees, displaced persons, and vulnerable communities;

the implications for communities vulnerable
			 to health effects of climate change, as well as strategies for responding to
			 climate change within these communities; and

local and
			 community-based health interventions for climate-related health impacts;

creating tools for
			 predicting and monitoring the public health effects of climate change on the
			 international, national, regional, State, and local levels, and providing
			 technical support to assist in their implementation;

identifying and prioritizing communities
			 and populations vulnerable to the health effects of climate change, and
			 determining actions and communication strategies that should be taken to inform
			 and protect these communities and populations from the health effects of
			 climate change;

developing health
			 communication, public education, and outreach programs aimed at public health
			 and health care professionals, as well as the general public, to promote
			 preparedness and response strategies relating to climate change and public
			 health, including the identification of greenhouse gas reduction behaviors that
			 are health-promoting;

developing
			 academic and regional centers of excellence devoted to—

researching relationships between climate
			 change and health;

expanding and
			 training the public health workforce to strengthen the capacity of such
			 workforce to respond to and prepare for the health effects of climate
			 change;

creating and
			 supporting academic fellowships focusing on the health effects of climate
			 change; and

training senior
			 health ministry officials from developing nations to strengthen the capacity of
			 such nations to—

prepare for and
			 respond to the health effects of climate change; and

using techniques, including health impact
			 assessments, to assess various climate change public health preparedness and
			 response strategies on international, national, State, regional, tribal, and
			 local levels, and make recommendations as to those strategies that best protect
			 the public health;

assisting in the
			 development, implementation, and support of State, regional, tribal, and local
			 preparedness, communication, and response plans (including with respect to the
			 health departments of such entities) to anticipate and reduce the health
			 threats of climate change; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
or an appropriate Federal agency, pursuing
			 collaborative efforts to develop, integrate, and implement such plans;

			 for Disease Control and Prevention

			 for Disease Control and Prevention

			 effects preparedness and response strategies;

prioritize
			 critical public health infrastructure projects related to potential climate

providing technical assistance for the
			 development, implementation, and support of preparedness and response plans to
			 anticipate and reduce the health threats of climate change in developing

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to plan for and respond to the impacts of climate

carrying out other activities determined

the impacts of

advances in the

authority under this Act and other Federal statutes to achieve the goals and

and Federal officials of
			 other relevant Federal agencies shall administer public health programs and
			 initiatives authorized by statutes other than this Act, subject to the
			 requirements of such statutes, in a manner designed to achieve the goals of the
			 national strategic action plan.
